titleStmt.title: The lovers fancy. Or True love requited with constancy being a civil discourse between John and Anne. the young man he was constant unto the end, the maid at last she prov'd his loving friend: young men and maids that stand to hear this song, then mind it well, do not each other wrong: young men, prove constant, faithful, true and just, and then the maids may better to you trust. To the tune of Loves fancy.

The lovers fancy. Or True love requited with constancy being a civil discourse between John and Anne. the young man he was constant unto the end, the maid at last she prov'd his loving friend: young men and maids that stand to hear this song, then mind it well, do not each other wrong: young men, prove constant, faithful, true and just, and then the maids may better to you trust. To the tune of Loves fancy.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for F. Coles, T. Vere, J. Wright, and J. Clarke,

notesStmt.note: Verse - "As lately abroad I was walking,".
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
